technical.question: Is Harddisk a perfect example of ROM?
technical.answer: No, a hard disk is not a perfect example of ROM.
alternativeAnswers: A hard disk is not an example of ROM.
It is not true that a hard disk is a perfect example of ROM.

technical.question: What is UEFI?
technical.answer: UEFI is a type of BIOS.
alternativeAnswers: UEFI refers to BIOS.
It is a form of BIOS.

technical.question: IP filtering Firewall works on which layer?
technical.answer: An IP filtering Firewall works on layer 4.
alternativeAnswers: It operates on layer 4.
Layer 4 is the operational layer.

technical.question: NGFW works on which layer?
alternativeAnswers: It operates on layer 7.
Layer 7 is where NGFW operates.

technical.question: Is redundancy same as high availability?
technical.answer: No, redundancy is not the same as high availability.
alternativeAnswers: Redundancy and high availability are not identical.
They are not the same thing.

technical.question: What is POST?
technical.answer: POST stands for Power on self test.
alternativeAnswers: It is Power on self test.
Power on self test is what POST means.

technical.question: Do we still use Hubs in Offices?
technical.answer: No, we do not still use Hubs in Offices.
alternativeAnswers: Hubs are not used in offices anymore.
It is not common to use hubs in offices.

technical.question: Do home routers use BGP?
technical.answer: No, home routers do not use BGP.
alternativeAnswers: BGP is not used by home routers.
It is not true that home routers utilize BGP.

technical.question: CSMA/CD is still used in offices or not?
technical.answer: No, CSMA/CD is not still used in offices.
alternativeAnswers: CSMA/CD is no longer used in offices.
It is not common for offices to use CSMA/CD.

technical.question: Do we have other types of ports than TCP?
technical.answer: Yes, we have other types of ports than TCP.
alternativeAnswers: There are other ports besides TCP.
It is true that there are ports other than TCP.

listening.text: The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog.
To be or not to be is the question.

I tried to persevere but I can not sustain this anymore.
Please bear with me I appreciate your patience.

Please pay attention to your belongings.

logical.question: If all Bloops are Razzies and all Razzies are Lazzies, are all Bloops definitely Lazzies?
What is the meaning of corpulent?
A person who thinks only of himself is egoist or eccentric
Ram speaks less in the forum. Ram is reticent or garrulous
Savitri travels by foot. She is a stickler or pedestrian
the government by a king or queen is called autocracy or monarchy
A life history written by somebody else is biography or autobiography
The act of murder of a human being is homicide or patricide.
Study of birds is called ornithology or zoology.
Rohit is greedy for money, is he avaricious or spendthrift.

grammar.question: Rearrange the words to form a correct sentence: 'only after the meeting started she realized had forgotten her notes.'
grammar.answer: Only after the meeting started did she realize she had forgotten her notes.
alternativeAnswers: She realized she had forgotten her notes only after the meeting started.
Only after the meeting started did she realize that she had forgotten her notes.

grammar.question: Rearrange the words to form a correct sentence: 'rarely have I seen such a breathtaking view.'
grammar.answer: Rarely have I seen such a breathtaking view.
alternativeAnswers: I have rarely seen such a breathtaking view.
Such a breathtaking view I have rarely seen.

grammar.question: Rearrange the words to form a correct sentence: 'not until the end of the movie we understood the twist.'
grammar.answer: Not until the end of the movie did we understand the twist.
alternativeAnswers: We did not understand the twist until the end of the movie.
Only at the end of the movie did we understand the twist.

grammar.question: Correct the subject-verb agreement in this sentence: 'Neither of the candidates have submitted their proposals.'
grammar.answer: Neither of the candidates has submitted their proposals.
alternativeAnswers: Neither candidate has submitted their proposals.
Neither of the candidates has submitted his or her proposals.

grammar.question: Correct the subject-verb agreement in this sentence: 'The committee are divided in their opinions.'
grammar.answer: The committee is divided in its opinions.
alternativeAnswers: The committee is divided in their opinions.
The committee members are divided in their opinions.

grammar.question: Correct the subject-verb agreement in this sentence: 'Each of the students were given a certificate.'
grammar.answer: Each of the students was given a certificate.
alternativeAnswers: Every student was given a certificate.
Each student was given a certificate.

grammar.question: Correct the subject-verb agreement in this sentence: 'The number of participants have increased this year.'
grammar.answer: The number of participants has increased this year.
alternativeAnswers: The number of participants has grown this year.
The number of participants has risen this year.

grammar.question: Replace the incorrect word in this sentence: 'His explanation was hardly comprehensible due to the technical jargons.'
grammar.answer: His explanation was hardly comprehensible due to the technical jargon.
alternativeAnswers: His explanation was hardly understandable due to the technical jargon.
His explanation was barely comprehensible due to the technical jargon.

grammar.question: Replace the incorrect word in this sentence: 'The criteria for selection is very strict.'
grammar.answer: The criteria for selection are very strict.
alternativeAnswers: The criterion for selection is very strict.
The standards for selection are very strict.

grammar.question: Replace the incorrect word in this sentence: 'She was completely unbeknownst to the plans.'
grammar.answer: She was completely unaware of the plans.
alternativeAnswers: She was completely ignorant of the plans.
She had no knowledge of the plans.

The importance of education in the 21st century

diction.story: Mr. Henry Thompson observed the cityscape from his office window. Tall buildings pierced the skyline, reflecting the morning sun. Busy streets below teemed with commuters and vehicles. The rhythmic hum of urban life filled the air. This daily panorama offered a constant source of fascination.

questions.question: Who observed the cityscape?
questions.answer: Mr. Henry Thompson observed the cityscape from his office window.
alternativeAnswers: Henry Thompson observed the cityscape from his window.
The cityscape was observed by Mr. Thompson.

questions.question: What pierced the skyline?
questions.answer: Tall buildings pierced the skyline, reflecting the morning sun.
alternativeAnswers: The skyline was pierced by tall buildings.
Buildings rose tall, reflecting morning sun.

questions.question: What teemed in the streets below?
questions.answer: Busy streets below teemed with commuters and vehicles.
alternativeAnswers: Commuters and vehicles teemed in the busy streets.
The streets were busy with commuters and cars.

questions.question: What filled the air?
questions.answer: The rhythmic hum of urban life filled the air.
alternativeAnswers: The air was filled by the hum of urban life.
Urban life's rhythmic hum permeated the air.

questions.question: What did this daily panorama offer?
questions.answer: This daily panorama offered a constant source of fascination.
alternativeAnswers: A constant source of fascination was offered.
It provided an ongoing source of intrigue.

diction.story: The research institute announced a significant scientific breakthrough. It concerned a novel approach to disease prevention. Scientists presented compelling evidence supporting their findings. The discovery promised profound implications for global public health. This achievement marked a new era in medical science.

questions.question: What did the research institute announce?
questions.answer: The research institute announced a significant scientific breakthrough.
alternativeAnswers: A significant scientific breakthrough was announced.
A major scientific discovery was declared.

questions.question: What did it concern?
questions.answer: It concerned a novel approach to disease prevention.
alternativeAnswers: A new approach to disease prevention was concerned.
It was about a new disease prevention method.

questions.question: What did scientists present?
questions.answer: Scientists presented compelling evidence supporting their findings.
alternativeAnswers: Compelling evidence supporting their findings was presented.
They showed strong evidence for their discoveries.

questions.question: What did the discovery promise?
questions.answer: The discovery promised profound implications for global public health.
alternativeAnswers: Profound implications for global health were promised.
It promised major impacts on world health.

questions.question: What did this achievement mark?
questions.answer: This achievement marked a new era in medical science.
alternativeAnswers: A new era in medical science was marked.
It signified a new time for medical science.
